description: From Middle English rop, rope, from Old English rāp (“rope, cord, cable”), from Proto-West Germanic *raip, from Proto-Germanic *raipaz, *raipą (“rope, cord, band, ringlet”), from Proto-Indo-European *h₁roypnós (“strap, band, rope”), from *h₁reyp- (“to peel off, tear; border, edge, strip”).

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Thick strings, yarn, monofilaments, metal wires, or strands of other cordage that are twisted together to form a stronger line.
examples: Synonyms: twine, line, cord; see also Thesaurus:string
Nylon rope is usually stronger than similar rope made of plant fibers.

entries.meaning: (countable) An individual length of such material.
examples: The swinging bridge is constructed of 40 logs and 30 ropes.

entries.meaning: (slang, vulgar) A shot of semen that a man releases during ejaculation.
(dated) A continuous stream.
(baseball) A hard line drive.
examples: He hit a rope past third and into the corner.

entries.meaning: (ceramics) A long thin segment of soft clay, either extruded or formed by hand.
(computer science) A data structure resembling a string, using a concatenation tree in which each leaf represents a character.
(military, uncountable) A kind of chaff (material dropped to interfere with radar) consisting of foil strips with paper chutes attached.
(Jainism) A unit of distance equivalent to the distance covered in six months by a god flying at ten million miles per second.
(jewelry) A necklace of at least 1 meter in length.
(nautical) Cordage of at least 1 inch in diameter, or a length of such cordage.
(archaic) A unit of length equal to 20 feet.
(slang) Rohypnol.
(slang, usually in the plural) Semen being ejaculated.
(with "the") Death by hanging.
examples: The murderer was sentenced to the rope.

description: From Middle English ropen, rope (“to form ropes”), from rop (“rope”); see above.

verbs.description: rope (third-person singular simple present ropes, present participle roping, simple past and past participle roped)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To tie (something) with rope.
(transitive) To throw a rope (or something similar, e.g. a lasso, cable, wire, etc.) around (something).
(intransitive) To climb by means of a rope or ropes.
examples: We roped down to the platform selected for the bivouac; set up our bags and brewed a reasonable meal.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be formed into rope; to draw out or extend into a filament or thread.
(incel slang, intransitive) To commit suicide, particularly by hanging.
examples: In figure 71, the poster Brahcel notes that he “almost roped” because he could not find the community  […]

description: From Middle English rop (“gut, intestine”), from Old English rop, ropp; compare Middle Dutch rop, roppe (“fish guts”).
The modern pronunciation results from phonological assimilation to Etymology 1.

entries.meaning: (in the plural) The small intestines.
